questions.text:
Identify the structure marked in red in the image given below.
Pulmonary trunk
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below
questions.solution:
On plain radiograph and CT the densities of the normal hilum are mainly due to blood vessels. Normal lymph nodes cannot be recognized as discrete structures, and the bronchial walls contribute little to the bulk of the hila, being thin and easily recognized for what they are. The right pulmonary artery passes anterior to the major bronchi, whereas the left pulmonary artery arches superior to the left main bronchus. The central portion of the right hilum consists of a combination of the right pulmonary artery and the superior pulmonary vein. As these two vessels are immediately adjacent to one another (on the left, the left main bronchus lies between them), they may be responsible for a density that is sufficiently great to be confused with a mass on lateral chest x-ray.

Option a is not correct as SVC lies more medially and superiorly.

Option c is not correct as IVC lies more medially and inferiorly.

Option d is not correct as the pointed structure is right side of the lung

KEY TAKEAWAY: On plain radiograph and CT the densities of the normal hilum are due mainly to blood vessels.

The central portion of the right hilum consists of a combination of the superior pulmonary vein (forms the upper limb of hilum) and pulmonary artery (forms the long lower limb of hilum).

LOWER LOBE PULMONARY VEINS never contribute to hilar shadows.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and chills. He also developed red colored sputum expectoration. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
K. pneumoniae is among the most common gram-negative bacteria causing pneumonia. The radiographic features include bulging fissures due to volume increase of the infected lobe, sharp margins of the advancing border of the pneumonic infiltrate and early abscess formation. The given image shows bulging fissure sign; suggestive of klebsiella pneumonia.

Option a is not correct as Streptococcus causes lobar pneumonia and a characteristic feature is presence of air bronchogram.

Option c and d are not correct as both Mycoplasma and Pneumocystis jirovecii causes interstitial pneumonia.


Lobar pneumonia

(Streptococcal pneumonia


Interstitial pneumonia


KEY TAKEAWAY:

Bulging fissure sign - K. pneumoniae

Air bronchogram sign - lobar pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumonia.

choices.text: Reconstructions using a high spatial frequency ('sharp' or 'lung') algorithm

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about HRCT scan of thorax?
questions.solution:
The essential requirements for a high-resolution CT (HRCT) technique are:

(1) thin collimation, usually 1 to 2 mm,

(2) reconstructions using a high spatial frequency ('sharp' or 'lung') algorithm and

(3) single breath-hold imaging, to obtain images undistorted by respiratory motion artefact.

The improved spatial resolution afforded by the thin collimation and the 'sharp' algorithm enhances the detection of key morphological features in HRCT interpretation, such as thickened interlobular septa, ground-glass opacification and abnormal subsegmental airways.

All the three options a, b and c are correct and option d is false.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image below.
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: A patient presented with breathlessness and cough to OPD. On eliciting the history, he was found to have a history of 27 pack year smoking history. He was advised to undergo a HRCT scan of the lungs. The following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with RB-ILD generally present with an insidious onset of dyspnea and cough. Chest radiography is relatively insensitive for the detection of RB-ILD. On HRCT, the features of RB-ILD include areas of patchy ground glass opacification (resulting from macrophage accumulation within alveolar spaces and alveolar ducts) and poorly defined low-attenuation centrilobular nodules. In addition, upper lobe centrilobular emphysema, usually of very limited extent, and areas of air trapping may be present, the latter reflecting the bronchiolitic element of this entity. In RB-ILD, scattered thickening of the interlobular septa and features of interstitial fibrosis can be seen, but this is not the dominant pattern. Thus, inconspicuous poorly defined centrilobular nodules of ground-glass opacification in symptomatic smokers are suggestive of RB-ILD.


Sarcoidosis has the following patterns of thoracic involvement i.e., bilateral, symmetrical hilar and paratracheal lymphadenopathy, which are not seen in RB-ILD. The affected lymph nodes may calcify, sometimes in a characteristic eggshell fashion in sarcoidosis.


Option A: Silicosis, seen in construction workers, sandblasting occupation.


ALSO KNOW: Distribution patterns of nodules.


KEY TAKEAWAY: RB-ILD and DIP are smoking related lung diseases.

Inconspicuous poorly defined centrilobular nodules of ground-glass opacification in symptomatic smokers are suggestive of RB-ILD

questions.text: A patient presented to a physician with complaint of long-standing breathlessness, palpitations and bilateral lower limb edema. The physician ordered an ECHO scan and HRCT of thorax to identify the cause of the symptoms. On ECHO screening, the changes of pulmonary arterial hypertension were documented. What is the most probable finding on HRCT?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a serious condition characterized by increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries, defined as a resting mean pulmonary arterial pressure greater than 20 mmHg. Understanding the risk factors, diagnostic imaging findings, and underlying causes is crucial for management.

Risk Factors

  1. Drugs and Toxins:
    • Aminorex (withdrawn)
    • Fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine
    • Toxic rapeseed oil
    • Amphetamines
    • L-tryptophan
  2. Other Conditions:
    • HIV infection (HIV-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension)
    • Portal hypertension and liver disease (portopulmonary hypertension)
    • Connective tissue diseases, such as scleroderma

Diagnostic Imaging

Plain Radiograph

  • Common Findings(90% of patients show abnormalities):
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy (elevated cardiac apex)
    • Enlarged right atrium
    • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
    • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
    • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

High-Resolution CT (HRCT) Chest

  • Extracardiac Vascular Signs:
    • Pulmonary Trunk Enlargement:
      • General predictive cutoff: >29 mm
    • Sex-Specific Values:
  1. Women: 27 mm
  2. Men: 29 mm

  • Pulmonary Artery to Ascending Aorta Ratio:
    • Normal: <1.0 in adults; up to ~1.09 in children.
  • Other Findings:
    • Enlarged pulmonary arteries, mural calcification in central pulmonary arteries, evidence of previous pulmonary emboli.
    • The segmental artery-to-bronchial diameter ratio of 1:1 to 1.25 or more, combined with a dilated main pulmonary artery, indicates pulmonary hypertension with high specificity

KEY TAKEAWAY: Carina Crossover Sign: Can be an important finding in the assessment of pulmonary hypertension.

Pulmonary Artery to Ascending Aorta Ratio:

  • Normal: <1.0 in adults; up to ~1.09 in children.

questions.text: A worker working in the glass industry presented with breathlessness for 6 months and was diagnosed with silicosis. Identify the feature shown below on HRCT
questions.solution:
Silicosis is a fibrotic pneumoconiosis caused by inhaling fine particles of crystalline silica. It's primarily associated with occupations like mining, quarrying, denim sandblasting, and tunneling. The disease has two main clinical forms based on the timing of exposure to silica:

Clinical Forms

  1. Acute Silicosis:
    • Manifests as alveolar silicoproteinosis.
    • Plain radiography includes bilateral consolidation and ground-glass opacities in perihilar regions.
    • CT Findings:Numerous bilateral centrilobular nodular ground-glass opacities, multifocal patchy ground-glass opacities, and consolidation.
  2. Classic Silicosis:
    • Manifests as chronic interstitial reticulonodular disease.
    • Divided into:
      • Simple Silicosis: Characterized by small, round or irregular opacities.
      • Complicated Silicosis: Presents as large conglomerate opacities indicative of progressive massive fibrosis.
    • Plain radiography shows Multiple well-defined nodular opacities (1-10 mm) predominantly in the upper lobes.
    • CT findings: Multiple small pulmonary nodules with upper lobe predominance and perilymphatic Subpleural nodules may coalesce into "candle wax" lesions or "pseudoplaques." Hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy can precede parenchymal nodules, often with eggshell calcification pattern.

3. Complicated Silicosis:

  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Large symmetric bilateral opacities (≥1 cm) with irregular margins, typically in the middle lung zones or peripheral lung.
    • Opacities may migrate toward the hilum.
  • CT:
    • Focal soft-tissue masses with irregular or ill-defined margins, often surrounded by emphysematous changes.

KEY TAKEAWAY: D/D of eggshell calcification.

  • Silicosis
  • Coal worker pneumoconiosis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A coal worker presented with chronic breathlessness and cough. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Progressive Massive Fibrosis (PMF) is characterized by the formation of large mass-like conglomerates in the lungs, particularly in the upper lobes. This condition is commonly associated with pneumoconiosis such as coal worker's pneumoconiosis and silicosis, though similar features can occur in talcosis.

Plain Radiograph

  • Large symmetric bilateral opacities with irregular margins, predominantly located in the upper lobes.

CT Scan

  • Mass-like areas of lung opacification, often described as "sausage-shaped."
  • Characteristic radiating strands may be present.
  • Regions commonly exhibit air bronchograms and may contain calcifications.
  • These mass-like areas can shrink over time and tend to migrate toward the hilar regions.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Progressive Massive Fibrosis can be seen in

  • Silicosis
  • coal worker's pneumoconiosis
  • talcosis

PMF indicates advanced disease progression in pneumoconiosis and can lead to significant respiratory impairment. Early recognition through imaging is crucial for appropriate management and monitoring of affected individuals.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Eggshell calcifications seen with classic interstitial reticulonodular disease in various conditions like silicosis, sarcoidosis, histoplasmosis, tuberculosis etc.

Option D: Alveolar silicoproteinosis is an acute form of silicosis. The imaging includes bilateral consolidation and ground-glass opacities in perihilar regions.

questions.text: Most useful marker for asbestos exposure in workers working in such environment is:
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers, leading to progressive pulmonary fibrosis, primarily affecting the lower lung zones. The risk of lung cancer is also increased in individuals with asbestosis, even in the absence of significant disease progression.

Plain Radiograph:

  • Irregular Opacities: Often exhibit a fine reticular pattern.
  • Pleural Plaques: May show calcified or noncalcified plaques, indicating prior asbestos exposure. They are the most useful markers.

CT Scan:

  • Early Manifestations:
    • Centrilobular Dot-like Opacities: Suggestive of peribronchial fibrosis.
    • Intralobular Linear Opacities: Indicative of reticulation.
    • Subpleural Lines: Often appear curvilinear.
  • These early changes can resemble dependent atelectasis, so obtaining both supine and prone scans can help in accurate diagnosis.
  • Progressive Findings:
    • Parenchymal Bands: Typically found in lower lung zones.
    • Traction Bronchiectasis: Indicates ongoing fibrosis.
    • Honeycomb Fibrosis: A sign of advanced disease.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Pleural effusions and pleural plaques are frequently observed in patients with asbestos-related conditions. Occasionally, mediastinal lymphadenopathy may also be present.

Pleural Plaques: May show calcified or non-calcified plaques, indicating prior asbestos exposure. They are the most useful marker.

questions.text: A coal miner developed breathlessness. He underwent a chest x-ray and was diagnosed as case of coal worker's pneumoconiosis. After 5 years on follow up, he developed pain in his hands. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Caplan syndrome, or rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, occurs in individuals with seropositive rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to occupational dust, particularly in pneumoconiosis. Originally described in coal miners, it can also arise from exposure to other types of dust.

Key Characteristics

  • Pathology: In contrast to typical rheumatoid arthritis, which features necrobiotic nodules, Caplan syndrome presents with nodules that have a dust ring of inflammatory cells (granulocytes, macrophages, and giant cells) surrounding a necrotic core. Dust particles may be found within the necrotic area and within macrophages.

Radiographic Features

  • Nodules: Typically, well-defined nodules ranging from 5 to 50 mm in size, predominantly located in the upper lung lobes or peripheral lung regions.
  • Nodule Changes: These nodules may remain unchanged, multiply, calcify or develop into thick-walled cavities.
  • Background Changes: There may be underlying changes indicative of pneumoconiosis.
  • Pleural Effusion: Accompanying pleural effusions can also be observed.
  • Growth Patterns: The nodules may grow in short bursts rather than gradually

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Felty syndrome is a triad of Rheumatoid arthritis, Splenomegaly and Neutropenia
  • Borchardt syndrome is characterized by upper abdominal pain due to intrathoracic stomach or upward displacement of the stomach,retching and inability to pass NG tube.
  • Caplan's syndrome is also known as rheumatoid pneumoconiosis.
  • Klippel-Feil syndrome can be classified into three types based on the number of fused vertebrae:

type I (fusion of all seven cervical vertebrae),

type II (fusion of the upper three cervical vertebrae), and

type III (fusion of the lower four cervical vertebra)

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presented to OPD with difficulty in swallowing and some difficulty in breathing. He also complained of drooping of eyelids and muscle fatigue. On getting a CXR following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Thymic epithelial tumors are rare neoplasms that arise from the thymus gland, located in the anterior mediastinum. They include thymomas, invasive thymomas, and thymic carcinoma, making them the most common primary tumors in this region, particularly in middle-aged patients. Associated with Myasthenia Gravis & Graves' Disease
  • Plain Radiography:Thymic epithelial tumors typically present as well-defined, lobulated soft tissue masses in the anterior mediastinum, often deviating slightly to one side.
  • On CTthese tumors usually have a cystic component is common, and calcifications can be observed in some. Thymoma shows soft tissue attenuation and are found between the sternum and the great vessels.

The patient mentioned above has features of myasthenia gravis and image showing anterior mediastinal soft tissue mass narrows down to diagnosis of thymoma, because MG is associated with thymomas (10%). However thymic hyperplasia (65%) is more common with MG.

Anterior mediastinal masses: Based on type of tissue


KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Thymomas are located in anterior mediastinum.
  • In a Patient presented with thymoma, always rule outMyasthenia Gravis and Graves' Disease.
  • 4 T' s of Anterior mediastinum
    • Thymoma
    • Terrible lymphoma
    • Thyroid goitre
    • Teratoma

questions.text: A patient presented to a physician with complaints of evening rise fever, cough and weight loss. Patient had similar history in the past 8 years ago. The physician ordered an Xray which is shown below. Identify the most likely organism responsible.
questions.solution:
Pulmonary manifestations of tuberculosis (TB) can vary significantly depending on whether the infection is primary or post-primary. The lungs are the most common site of primary infection and can lead to considerable morbidity and mortality.

Primary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

  • Asymptomatic Nature: Most cases are asymptomatic, but some may progress to symptomatic hematogenous dissemination, resulting in miliary TB.
  • Location of Infection:
    • In children, primary infection can occur anywhere in the lungs.
    • In adults, there's a predilection for the upper or lower lung zones.

Radiographic Features:

  • Initial Focus: Can range from undetectable to patchy or lobar consolidation. Parenchymal infection is seen in 70% of children and 90% of adults.
  • Cavitation: Uncommon in primary TB (10-30% of cases).
  • Ghon Complex: Formation of a caseating granuloma (tuberculoma), which may calcify over time.
  • Lymphadenopathy: Ipsilateral hilar and paratracheal lymphadenopathy is common, especially in children (90% of cases). In adults, this occurs in only 10-30% of cases.
  • Pleural Effusions: More common in adults (30-40%) than in children (5-10%).

Post-Primary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

Also known as reactivation TB, this occurs years after the initial infection, often in individuals with compromised immune status.

Radiographic Features:

  • Location of Infection: Typically found in the posterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.
  • Appearance: Patchy consolidation or poorly defined linear and nodular opacities.
  • Cavitation:More likely than in primary TB, seen in 20-45% of cases, primarily in the posterior segments of the upper lobes.
  • Air-Fluid Levels: Suggest communication with airways, indicating potential contagion. Endobronchial spread can result in "tree-in-bud" patterns on CT.
  • Lymphadenopathy: Less common, occurring in about one-third of cases.
  • Tuberculomas:Account for 5% of post-primary TB cases, typically well-defined and rounded, often in the upper lobes.

Miliary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

  • Nature: Represents hematogenous dissemination and is associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Radiographic Features: Appears as uniform 1-3 mm nodules, evenly distributed throughout the lungs.
  • Prognosis: If treated successfully, no residual abnormalities remain.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Ghon Focus: A small, well-defined, round or oval lesion often located in the lower lobe of the lung.
  • Simon Focus: A calcified lymph node located in the hilum of the lung.
  • Primary Complex: Consists of a Ghon focus, hilar lymph node enlargement, and sometimes a bronchogenic spread of lesions.
  • Cavitation: The formation of a hollow space within a lung lesion.
  • Consolidation: The filling of lung alveoli with fluid, pus, or other material.
  • Tuberculous Pleural Effusion: The accumulation of fluid in the pleural space
  • Miliary pattern mnemonic:

questions.text: Right Border of mediastinum on PA CXR is formed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Right border of mediastinum is formed by SVC, RA and IVC.

Left border of mediastinum is formed by LA and LV.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient had a history of tuberculosis 20 years ago, now came with complaint of fever and breathlessness. His HRCT scan showed the following image.

Identify the stage of disease
questions.solution:
Pulmonary manifestations of tuberculosis (TB) can vary significantly depending on whether the infection is primary or post-primary. The lungs are the most common site of primary infection and can lead to considerable morbidity and mortality.

Primary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

  • Asymptomatic Nature: Most cases are asymptomatic, but some may progress to symptomatic hematogenous dissemination, resulting in miliary TB.
  • Location of Infection:
    • In children, primary infection can occur anywhere in the lungs.
    • In adults, there's a predilection for the upper or lower lung zones.

Radiographic Features:

  • Initial Focus: Can range from undetectable to patchy or lobar consolidation. Parenchymal infection is seen in 70% of children and 90% of adults.
  • Cavitation:Uncommon in primary TB (10-30% of cases).
  • Ghon Complex:Formation of a caseating granuloma (tuberculoma), which may calcify over time.
  • Lymphadenopathy:Ipsilateral hilar and paratracheal lymphadenopathy is common, especially in children (90% of cases). In adults, this occurs in only 10-30% of cases.
  • Pleural Effusions: More common in adults.

  • Post-Primary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

Also known as reactivation TB, this occurs years after the initial infection, often in individuals with compromised immune status.

Radiographic Features:

  • Location of Infection: Typically found in the posterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.
  • Appearance: Patchy consolidation or poorly defined linear and nodular opacities.
  • Cavitation: More likely than in primary TB, seen in 20-45% of cases, primarily in the posterior segments of the upper lobes.
  • Air-Fluid Levels: Suggest communication with airways, indicating potential contagion. Endobronchial spread can result in "tree-in-bud" patterns on CT.
  • Lymphadenopathy: Less common, occurring in about one-third of cases.
  • Tuberculomas: Account for 5% of post-primary TB cases, typically well-defined and rounded, often in the upper lobes.

Miliary Pulmonary Tuberculosis

  • Nature: Represents hematogenous dissemination and is associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Radiographic Features: Appears as uniform 1-3 mm nodules, evenly distributed throughout the lungs.
  • Prognosis: If treated successfully, no residual abnormalities remain.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Identify the type of ILD shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is a broad term encompassing various disorders characterized by diffuse cellular infiltrates affecting the lung interstitium. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is a specific histopathologic and radiologic pattern within this spectrum, associated with conditions such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Diagnosis typically involves a multidisciplinary team.

Radiographic Features

Plain Radiograph

  • Non-Specific Findings: In early disease, chest radiographs may appear normal. In advanced stages, findings may include:
    • Decreased Lung Volumes:Reflective of advanced disease.
    • Reticulation: Fineto coarse reticular patterns, predominantly in the lower lobes.
    • Shift of Major Fissure:Inferior shift of the major fissure due to extensive lower lobe involvement, best visualized on lateral views.

CT Scan

  • High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Specific diagnostic criteria for UIP include:
    • Honeycombing: Highly specific if involving more than 5% of lung parenchyma. A distinction can be made between cases with <5% and >5% honeycombing, reflecting the stage and severity of the disease.
    • Traction Bronchiectasis: Indicating lung fibrosis with dilated bronchi.
    • .Reticular Opacities: Located primarily in the subpleural regions, often associated with honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis, with a predominance in the peripheral and lower lobes

KEY TAKEAWAY: specific signs of UIP.

Reticular Opacities located primarily in the subpleural regions, often associated with honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis, with a predominance in the peripheral and lower lobes

INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASES RADIOLOGICAL IDENTIFICATION:

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented to OPD with difficulty in breathing and few episodes of breathlessness on exertion. He was advised to undergo a CT scan which is shown below. He was advised to cease smoking following which there was improvement in his clinical condition. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Pulmonary emphysema is characterized by the abnormal and permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles, accompanied by the destruction of alveolar walls without significant fibrosis.

Risk Factors

  • Smoking: The leading cause, accounting for approximately 90% of cases.
  • Alpha-1-Antitrypsin Deficiency: A rare genetic condition that can lead to emphysema.
  • Ritalin Lung: A rare form associated with intravenous injection of methylphenidate.

Radiographic Features

Plain Radiograph

While chest X-rays do not directly visualize emphysema until advanced stages, they imply a diagnosis through associated features:

  • Hyperinflation: Increased lung volumes.
  • Flattened Hemidiaphragms: The most reliable sign of emphysema.
  • Irregular Radiolucency: Increased and often irregular lucency of lung fields.
  • Increased Retrosternal Airspace: Notable airspace behind the sternum.
  • Increased Anteroposterior Diameter: Widening of the chest.
  • Widely Spaced Ribs: Increased spacing between ribs.
  • Sternal Bowing: Anterior protrusion of the sternum.
  • Tenting of the Diaphragm: Diaphragm may appear tented upwards.
  • Saber-Sheath Trachea: Tracheal narrowing resembling a saber.
  • Blunting of Costophrenic Angles: Lateral and posterior costophrenic angles appear rounded.
  • Vascular Changes:
    • Paucity of blood vessels, often distorted.
    • Signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension, such as pruning of peripheral vessels and increased caliber of central arteries.
    • Right ventricular enlargement may occur due to cor pulmonale.

It's important to note that many patients with COPD can have a "normal" chest X-ray, so the primary role of imaging is to rule out other causes of lung symptoms.

CT Scan

CT, particularly high-resolution CT (HRCT), is the preferred modality for detecting emphysema. However, there is a poor correlation between autopsy-proven emphysema and imaging results, as some cases may not be evident on CT, while others with abnormal CT may have normal pulmonary function tests.

KEY TAKEAWAY: chest x ray of emphysema showing

Hyperinflation

Flattened diaphragm

Vertical heart

Avascular zones.


In all types, the emphysematous spaces lack visible walls, contributing to the characteristic imaging findings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker presented to OPD with complaints of right shoulder pain radiating to right arm and drooping of eyelid. Chest X-Ray was ordered which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a specific type of lung cancer that occurs at the apex of the lung and often invades surrounding soft tissues. While they can present with Pancoast syndrome, which includes shoulder pain, Horner syndrome, and arm pain, this syndrome is only seen in about 25% of cases. Common symptoms also include significant weight loss.

Plain radiography shows a soft tissue opacity at the lung apex.

Ultrasound has limited value in the evaluation of Pancoast tumors but can assist in percutaneous biopsy by visualizing the external tumor components via an intercostal or supraclavicular acoustic window.

CT Scan has limitations in local staging, with low sensitivity

MRI provides superior detail regarding soft-tissue involvement and has much higher sensitivity

Brachial plexus involvement of more than the lower trunk (C8 nerve root) generally indicates inoperability

KEY TAKEAWAY: Pancoast tumor is a rare type of lung cancer that originates in the upper lobe of the lung. It can spread to nearby structures, including the ribs, nerves, and blood vessels.

Symptom includes:

Severe shoulder pain

Arm pain or weakness

Loss of sensation in the arm or hand

Horner's syndrome (a condition that affects the eye and face)

Hoarseness

Difficulty swallowing

questions.text: A non-smoker female patient presented to OPD with complaints of productive cough and weight loss. On CXR following image was obtained and sputum examination showed malignant cells. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma of the Lung Overview

Adenocarcinoma is the most prevalent histologic type of lung cancer. Early symptoms often include fatigue and mild dyspnea, which may progress to chronic cough and hemoptysis.

Radiographic Features

  • Nodule Classification: Lung nodules are characterized as rounded or irregular regions of increased attenuation, which can be classified as:
    • Ground Glass: Corresponds to lepidic growth patterns, often indicating preinvasive or minimally invasive adenocarcinomas.
    • Subsolid: Features both ground-glass and solid components; may indicate a more invasive nature depending on the solid component.
    • Solid: Typically represents invasive subtypes of adenocarcinoma.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Adenocarcinoma prevalent mostly in nonsmoker female.

symptoms of adenocarcinoma:

Shortness of breath: This is often an early symptom.

Coughing

Chest pain: sharp or dull.

Wheezing

Unexplained weight loss.

Fatigue

Hoarseness

questions.text: A patient had a history of seizures which was not controlled with medications. On doing a CT scan of the brain, it was observed that he had cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. What would be expected on the cardiac imaging of such patient?
questions.solution:
Cardiac Rhabdomyomas

Cardiac rhabdomyomas are benign tumors of the myocardium and are the most common fetal cardiac tumor. They are notably associated with tuberous sclerosis, with over 50% of cases linked to this condition.

Radiographic Features

Ultrasound/Echocardiography

  • Appearance: Rhabdomyomas appear as one or more solid hyperechoic masses within the myocardium.
  • Mimicking Conditions: Small lesions can sometimes mimic diffuse myocardial thickening.
  • Location: Typically located in relation to the ventricles.
  • Size: Detected lesions in utero can range from 10 to 50 mm.

MRI

  • T1-weighted Imaging: Rhabdomyomas are isointense compared to adjacent myocardium.
  • T2-weighted Imaging: They appear hyperintense relative to the surrounding myocardium.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Cardiac rhabdomyomas are benign tumors that develop in the heart muscle. They are most commonly found in children, but can also occur in adults. They may be associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Symptoms:

  • Arrhythmias
  • Heart failure
  • Sudden cardiac death rarely.

Cardiac myxoma are seen with carney complex. Note that carney's triad is different

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with fatigue and breathlessness for 6 months and itchy red painful rashes on lower legs. On CXR the following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is a non-caseating granulomatous disease that can affect multiple organ systems, with variable clinical and radiographic manifestations.

Clinical Presentation

  • Asymptomatic: About 50% of patients may not exhibit symptoms.
  • Symptomatic: Remaining patients may present with:
    • Respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, dyspnea)
    • Skin conditions (e.g., erythema nodosum, lupus pernio)
    • Ocular and glandular involvement (e.g., lacrimal and salivary glands)
    • Neurosarcoidosis (in ~5% of cases)
  • Löfgren Syndrome: An acute form with a favorable prognosis. Associated with Erythema nodosum.
  • Heerfordt Syndrome: Features fever, parotid enlargement, facial palsy, and anterior uveitis.

Radiographic Features

Chest x-ray is Less sensitive than CT; may appear normal despite pulmonary granulomas (5-10% of cases).

1-2-3 Sign (Garland Triad): Classic pattern indicating hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

CT is More sensitive than X-ray, particularly for hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy


Chest x-ray given above shows bilateral hilar along with right paratracheal lymphadenopathy representing lamda sign

KEY TAKEAWAY: Lymphadenopathy Patterns in sarcoidosis

  • 1-2-3 Sign (Garland Triad):Classic pattern indicating hilar and mediastinal involvement.

questions.text: A child presented with breathlessness. He had a history of ingesting a foreign body. Identify the location of foreign body.
questions.solution:
Airway foreign bodies can pose a serious risk, particularly in children. Immediate recognition and management are crucial due to the potential for life-threatening complications.

  • Tend to lodge in the right tracheobronchial tree due to the anatomy of the bronchi; the right main bronchus is wider and has a steeper angle compared to the left.

Plain Radiograph

  • Radiographs should ideally be taken on expiration to enhance the visibility of lung differences.
  • In young children, caregivers can assist by applying inward and upward pressure to the abdomen to encourage expiration.
  • Findings:
    • Affected Lung: Appears overinflated and hyperlucent due to the "check valve" effect-air enters but does not exit around the foreign body.
    • Normal Lung: Appears smaller and denser compared to the affected lung.
    • Signs of Overinflation:
      • Rib flaring
      • Depressed ipsilateral hemidiaphragm
    • Interrupted Bronchus Sign: A potential indicator of airway obstruction.
    • Normal X-ray Results: Approximately 35% of patients may have a normal chest X-ray, especially if the foreign body is radiolucent.

Orientation of Foreign Bodies

  • Tracheal Foreign Bodies: Typically appear in the sagittal plane; coins may present as flat radiopaque circles on lateral films.
  • Esophageal Foreign Bodies: Generally oriented in the coronal plane; coins will appear as flat radiopaque circles on AP films.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Aspirated Foreign body in trachea.

Affected Lung appears overinflated and hyperlucent due to the "check valve" effect-air enters but does not exit around the foreign body.

Normal Lung appears smaller and denser compared to the affected lung.

questions.text: An infant presented with difficulty in breathing after birth. An x ray was done which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diaphragmatic hernias (or hernia) are defects in the diaphragm that can be congenital or acquired.

Plain Radiograph

  • Appearance:
    • Indistinct diaphragm
    • Opacification of part or all of the hemithorax, typically on the left side
    • Scaphoid abdomen(sunken appearance)
    • Deviation of trachea, mediastinum
  • Associated Findings:
    • Endotracheal tube positioning
    • Nasogastric tube placement
    • Umbilical arterial and venous catheters

Antenatal Ultrasound

  • Polyhydramnios
  • Cardio mediastinal shift with possible abnormal cardiac axis
  • Inability to visualize the normal stomach bubble

KEY TAKEAWAY: chest X-ray findings in CDH.

  • Mediastinal shift: The heart and mediastinum are shifted towards the unaffected side.
  • Bowel herniation: Loops of bowel can be seen in the chest cavity, often on the left side.
  • Lung hypoplasia: The lung on the affected side may be smaller and less developed due to compression.
  • Fluid accumulation: Pleural effusion or pericardial effusion may be present.

Look at the diaphragm whether it is intact or not, in the given image the diaphragm location is not intact which means it is CDH. A similar imaging is possible when there is diaphragmatic eventration but it is differentiated with the help of fluoroscopy. When the diaphragm is in its location pulmonary cysts is possible explanation.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
KEY TAKEAWAY


TGA

TAPVC

PAPVC

ENDOCARDIAL CUSHION DEFECT

TETROLOGY OF FALLOT

EBSTEIN ANOMALY

COARCTATION OF AORTA

questions.text: "Box shaped heart" is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ebstein anomaly is indeed a complex congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal development of the tricuspid valve.

Associations

  • Chromosomal Anomalies:
    • Trisomy 13
    • Trisomy 21
    • Turner Syndrome
  • Congenital Heart Lesions: Atrial septal defect(ASD) is common.

Radiographic Findings

  • Chest Radiograph:
    • Right-sided cardiomegaly, particularly an enlarged right atrium, can lead to an elevated cardiac apex.
    • The heart may appear "box-shaped" on frontal views, indicating the displacement of the tricuspid valve.

Diagnostic Criteria

  • Tricuspid Valve Displacement:
    • If the septal attachment of the tricuspid valve is more than 1.5 cm (2 cm in adults) below the mitral valve septal attachment, this is indicative of Ebstein anomaly.
  • "Atrialization" of the right ventricle andtricuspid regurgitation.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: "Scimitar Sign" seen in?
questions.solution:
Scimitar syndrome, or hypogenetic lung syndrome, is a rare congenital condition primarily characterized by a hypoplastic right lung and an anomalous pulmonary vein that drains into the systemic venous system, often leading to partial anomalous pulmonary venous return (PAPVR). Here's a concise overview:

Key Features

  • Pulmonary Hypoplasia: The right lung is underdeveloped.
  • Anomalous Pulmonary Vein: The hypoplastic lung's blood is typically returned to the inferior vena cava (most common), right atrium, or portal vein.
  • Shunting: Results in an acyanotic left-to-right shunt.

Radiographic Findings

  • Chest X-ray:
    • Displays a small, hypoplastic right lung with a shift of the mediastinum towards the affected side.
    • In about one-third of cases, the anomalous draining vein can be visualized as a tubular structure paralleling the right heart border, resembling a scimitar or Turkish sword.
    • The right heart border may appear blurred due to the associated structural changes.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Scimitar syndrome.

Hypoplasia: The right lung may be smaller or underdeveloped.

Pulmonary sequestration: A portion of the lung may receive its blood supply from the aorta instead of the pulmonary artery.

Dextroposition: The heart may be shifted to the right side of the chest.

questions.text: IDENTIFY THE SPOTTER AND GIVE THE DIAGNOSIS?
questions.solution:
The "gooseneck sign" is a radiographic finding often associated with atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD). It describes the appearance of the heart on chest X-rays, where the left atrium and left ventricle are positioned in such a way that the outline resembles the neck of a goose.

Endocardial cushion defect is associated with DOWN'S syndrome.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

The "gooseneck sign" is a radiographic finding often associated with atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD).

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease, characterized by narrowing of the aortic valve opening.

  • Classic Triad of Symptoms:

Angina Pectoris: Chest pain due to decreased coronary perfusion.

Dyspnea: Difficulty breathing, especially on exertion.

Syncope: Fainting episodes, often during exertion.

Heart Failure Symptoms: As the condition progresses, symptoms of heart failure may emerge, particularly once the aortic valve area falls below 1 cm2.

Plain Radiograph

  • Early Disease:
    • May appear normal or show dilatation of the ascending aorta (red arrow) with a normal-sized heart.
    • Differentiation from hypertension is possible, as hypertension typically involves enlargement of the entire descending aorta.
  • Late Disease:
    • Valvular calcifications may be visible, especially in cases of degenerative (calcific) aortic stenosis.
    • Cardiomegaly may be present along with signs of heart failure, such as pulmonary venous congestion and edema.

CT Imaging

  • Cardiac CT:
    • Provides detailed anatomical assessment, confirming findings from chest radiographs.
    • Can calculate an aortic valve calcification score, where a higher score may indicate severe stenosis, especially in non-rheumatic cases.
    • May show post-stenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, indicating changes due to the obstruction.

MRI Imaging

  • Cardiac MRI
    • Offers detailed structural and dynamic assessments of the aortic valve and left ventricle.
  • Structural Assessment:
    • Identifies the presence of bicuspid or unicuspid aortic valves.
    • Assesses post-stenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta.
    • Evaluates left ventricular hypertrophy (wall thickness ≥12 mm) and increased LV mass.
  • Dynamic Assessment:
    • Analyzes valve leaflet motion, showing thickened leaflets with reduced excursion during systole.
    • Evaluates the size and extent of the high-velocity jet into the ascending aorta.
    • Assesses hyperdynamic left ventricular contraction in the compensated state.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Cardiac CT:

  • Provides detailed anatomical assessment, confirming findings from chest radiographs.
  • Can calculate an aortic valve calcification score, where a higher score may indicate severe stenosis, especially in non-rheumatic cases.
  • May show post-stenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, indicating changes due to the obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain and dyspnea on exertion. On undergoing an MRI examination of the heart, it was observed that ventricular wall measures >15 mm and there was presence of mitral regurgitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is a condition characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, particularly affecting the left ventricle, which can obstruct blood flow.

Radiographic Features

Chest X-ray

  • Cardiomegaly: Mild to moderate enlargement of the heart may be observed, particularly of the left ventricle.
  • Pulmonary Congestion: In cases of heart failure, there may be signs of pulmonary venous congestion or interstitial edema.
  • Apical "Sugarloaf" Configuration: This characteristic shape may be noted due to the asymmetric septal hypertrophy.

Cardiac MRI

  • Detailed Assessment: MRI is excellent for evaluating the morphology and function of the heart.
    • Hypertrophy Patterns: Can visualize the extent and distribution of hypertrophy (e.g., asymmetric septal hypertrophy).
    • Dynamic Assessment: Evaluates the impact of the hypertrophy on left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction during different phases of the cardiac cycle.
    • Late Gadolinium Enhancement: May indicate fibrosis, which can have prognostic implications.

KEY TAKEAWAY: cardiac MRI - Evaluates the impact of the hypertrophy on left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction during different phases of the cardiac cycle.

choices.text: Double density sign with right atrial enlargement
Double density sign with left atrial enlargement

questions.text: A patient suffering from RHD presented with dyspnea. On doing a CXR the following image was obtained. What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a complication of rheumatic fever, characterized by damage to the heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves.

Radiographic Features

Chest X-ray

  • Cardiomegaly: Commonly observed due to left atrial and left ventricular enlargement, particularly in mitral valve disease.
  • Pulmonary Congestion: Signs of heart failure may include pulmonary vascular congestion and interstitial edema.
  • Left Atrial Enlargement: The left atrium may be enlarged, leading to a characteristic "double density" sign or a prominent left atrial contour.
  • Pleural Effusions: May be present as a result of heart failure or associated conditions.
  • Mitral Valve Calcification: In chronic cases, calcification of the mitral valve may be noted.
  • Walking man sign shown in image above.

Cardiac MRI

  • Valvular Morphology: Assesses the severity of valvular dysfunction and any associated regurgitation or stenosis.
  • Myocardial Involvement: Can evaluate myocardial edema or fibrosis, which may be present in active rheumatic fever or chronic RHD.

CT Imaging

  • Less Commonly Used: While not the primary modality, CT can be used in specific cases.
    • Valvular Calcification: Can identify calcification of the valves, particularly in chronic cases.
    • Assessment of Complications: Can evaluate for other associated conditions such as aortic aneurysms.

KEY TAKEAWAY: In Rheumatic heart disease

  • As the mitral valve narrows, the left atrium has to work harder to pump blood through the stenotic valve.
  • This increased pressure can cause the left atrium to enlarge.
  • Theenlarged left atrium can extend behind the right cardiac shadow, creating a double density appearance on a chest X-ray
  • Third mogul sign refers to prominences on left mediastinal border.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with grade IV dyspnea. Given below is a CXR. Which of the following is not seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Congestive cardiac failure (CCF), also known as congestive heart failure (CHF), results from various structural and functional abnormalities of the heart, leading to symptoms such as dyspnea, fatigue, and fluid retention.

Plain Radiograph

  • Left-sided Congestive Cardiac Failure:
    • Pulmonary Venous Congestion: Increased density in the upper lobes due to elevated pressure in pulmonary veins.
    • Cephalization of Pulmonary Veins: Redistribution of blood flow to the upper lobes, appearing as enlarged upper lobe veins compared to lower lobes.
    • Cardiomegaly: Enlarged heart may or may not be evident, depending on the underlying cause.
    • Pulmonary Interstitial Edema: Kerley B lines (horizontal lines at the lung periphery) indicating interstitial fluid.
    • Pulmonary Alveolar Edema: "Bat wing" pattern of opacification in the perihilar regions due to fluid accumulation in the alveoli.
    • Pleural Effusion: Blunting of the costophrenic angles may indicate fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Interpretation of chest X-rays for CCF.

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Double aortic arch is a congenital condition where there are two aortic arches that encircle the trachea and esophagus, potentially leading to compression of these structures. This condition can be associated with various symptoms, including stridor, difficulty swallowing, and respiratory distress.

Plain Radiograph

  • Chest X-ray:
    • Tracheal Deviation: The trachea may be displaced due to the encircling aortic arches.
    • Cardiac Silhouette: The heart may appear enlarged or have an unusual shape due to the presence of double arches.
    • Mediastinal Widening: A widened mediastinum can suggest vascular anomalies, including double aortic arch.
    • Aortic Arch Configuration: In some cases, the double aortic arch may be evident as two prominent arch-like structures.

OTHER OPTIONS:


KEY TAKEAWAY: clinical features of double aortic arch.

Stridor

Difficult swallowing

Respiratory distress

questions.text: A chronically bedridden patient developed breathing difficulty and underwent a CTPA which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in the pulmonary arteries, often caused by blood clots that travel to the lungs from the legs or other parts of the body (deep vein thrombosis).

Chest X-ray
  • Often Normal: Many patients with PE may have normal chest X-rays.
  • Possible Findings:
    • Atelectasis: Partial collapse of lung tissue.
    • Pleural Effusion: Fluid accumulation in the pleural space, which may be observed in some cases.
    • Westermark Sign: Regional oligemia(decreased blood flow) indicating a vascular obstruction (not commonly seen).
    • Hampton's Hump: A wedge-shaped opacityin the periphery of the lung, indicating infarction (also not commonly seen).
CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA)
  • Gold Standard
  • Findings:
    • Filling Defect: Direct visualization of the thrombus within the pulmonary artery or its branches as a filling defect.
    • Segmental and Subsegmental Emboli: Can show various levels of embolization.
    • Right Heart Strain: Signs such as right ventricular dilation may be present due to increased pressure.
    • Pleural Effusions: Often associated with PE.

Saddle Thrombus

A saddle thrombus is a large blood clot that straddles the bifurcation of the pulmonary arteries, blocking blood flow to both lungs. This is a more severe form of pulmonary embolism.

CT Pulmonary Angiography

  • Key Diagnostic Tool: CTPA is also used to identify saddle thrombus.
  • Findings:
    • Large Filling Defect: A thrombus that spans across the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery into the right and left pulmonary arteries. Also known as saddle thrombus.
    • Associated Signs: May show signs of right ventricular strain, such as right ventricular dilation or interventricular septal flattening.

KEY TAKEAWAY: CTPA is gold standard in diagnosing pulmonary embolism.

Some chest x ray findings are:

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is a rare, large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It often leads to stenosis, occlusion, and aneurysm formation.

The image given shows thickening of arteries.

Chest X-ray

  • Aortic Aneurysm: May show widening of the mediastinum or aortic dilation, indicating potential aneurysm formation.
  • Calcifications: Possible calcification in the aorta and its branches, though often subtle.

Ultrasound

  • Doppler Ultrasound: Useful for assessing blood flow in the aorta and its branches.
    • Stenosis: Can detect areas of narrowing or occlusion.
    • Aneurysms: Visualization of any aneurysmal dilatations.

CT Angiography (CTA)

  • Gold Standard: CTA is often the preferred imaging modality for Takayasu arteritis.
  • Findings:
    • Aortic Involvement: Demonstrates thickening of the aortic wall, narrowing of the lumen, and occlusion of the aorta or its branches.
    • Stenosis or Occlusion: Identifies affected branches (e.g., subclavian, carotid, renal arteries).
    • Aneurysms: Can visualize any aneurysms that may have formed.
    • Vascular Calcifications: May be seen in chronic cases.

MRI

  • Detailed Assessment: MRI provides excellent soft tissue contrast and is useful for assessing vascular involvement.
    • Wall Thickening: Can show thickening of the arterial walls.
    • Aneurysms and Stenosis: Provides information on the presence and extent of aneurysms or stenosis.
    • Inflammation: May demonstrate signs of inflammation in the vessel walls.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Takayasu arteritis is also known as "pulseless disease" due to the decreased or absent pulse in the affected arteries.

Key Characteristics:

  • Vasculitis: Inflammation of the blood vessels.
  • Aorta and Branches: Primarily affects the main artery leading from the heart (aorta) and its major branches.
  • Stenosis or Occlusion: Can lead to narrowing or blockage of arteries.
  • Aneurysms: May cause weakened artery walls to bulge.
